title: How to Make Model Horse Jumps

steps.headline: Decide what types of jumps you'd like to make.
steps.description:
If you're not sure what types of jumps exist, do an image search for horse jumps online. For example, you can make a log jump, corner jump, steps jump, or a castle jump. Keep in mind what materials you have and not making the jump too complicated. A log jump can be as simple as finding a piece of wood that looks like a log. Here is an example of a jump with bars:
Here is another type of jump:

steps.headline: Decide whether you want quickly made jumps that will be impermanent or permanent jumps that can be stored and brought out and played with again.
steps.description: Impermanent jumps can be set up on the spot, wherever you are. For example, if you're outdoors, you can help stones up. Permanent jumps will usually require a base or stand, and some gluing, nailing or tying methods used to keep the jump in one piece.

steps.headline: Make an impermanent jump using twigs, small branches, craft sticks and so forth.
steps.description: You will need to either balance the items in place or use some basic structural supports to keep the jump upright.

steps.headline: Make a twig jump.
steps.description: Choose four sturdy twigs of the same size as posts. Choose lots of thin sticks around the same size for the fence material of the jump. Poke the four post sticks into the ground in pairs at a length that is less than the fence twigs. Keep the paired posts close together, with just enough room to slide in the twigs. Pile the twigs in, and the posts will hold them in place as they build up to form the jump. Make it as high as you please.

steps.headline: Make a jump from craft sticks.
steps.description: Simply build up a jump by laying craft sticks one on top of the other to the desired height. You could use rubber bands or twist ties to keep the jump in place if you're worried about knocking it over

steps.headline: Make a jump from scrap wood or wood blocks.
steps.description: Find wood pieces that already look as if they'll make a great jump. You can use them as they are if sufficiently large, or build them into a small wall jump.

steps.headline: Turn the impermanent jumps into durable jumps by building them on a base then gluing or tying them into place.
steps.description: Keep them in a shoebox or similar container for safe keeping.

steps.headline: Find suitable stones in the garden.
steps.description: You can use stones, pebbles, river rocks, clods of earth and so forth.

steps.headline: Assemble the rocks into a wall by piling them one on top of the other.
steps.description: If you are concerned that the wall may fall over, prop them up with some twigs or craft sticks on the sides.

steps.headline: Turn the impermanent jumps into durable jumps by building them on a base then gluing or tying them into place.
steps.description: Keep them in a shoebox or similar container for safe keeping.

steps.headline: Find suitable materials to make bars with.
steps.description: Here are some suggestions for adding bars:

steps.headline: Pipes are ideal bars and they don't cost very much.
steps.description: These can be arranged vertically and diagonally on a structure made from sticks, craft sticks or blocks of wood. If you want to make them very fancy, the ends can be colored with a marker. Use pipe cleaners. Pipe cleaners are nice and light to use for bars. They can balance very easily off different materials and have the added advantage of being bendable and can be twisted, as needed. Use ribbons. Ribbons from the scrap basket can be cut to any lengths as wished, and tied or held on as bars on a jump.

text:
Steps Decide what types of jumps you'd like to make. If you're not sure what types of jumps exist, do an image search for horse jumps online. For example, you can make a log jump, corner jump, steps jump, or a castle jump. Keep in mind what materials you have and not making the jump too complicated. A log jump can be as simple as finding a piece of wood that looks like a log. Here is an example of a jump with bars:
Here is another type of jump: Decide whether you want quickly made jumps that will be impermanent or permanent jumps that can be stored and brought out and played with again. Impermanent jumps can be set up on the spot, wherever you are. For example, if you're outdoors, you can help stones up. Permanent jumps will usually require a base or stand, and some gluing, nailing or tying methods used to keep the jump in one piece. Basic wood jumps Make an impermanent jump using twigs, small branches, craft sticks and so forth. You will need to either balance the items in place or use some basic structural supports to keep the jump upright. Make a twig jump. Choose four sturdy twigs of the same size as posts. Choose lots of thin sticks around the same size for the fence material of the jump. Poke the four post sticks into the ground in pairs at a length that is less than the fence twigs. Keep the paired posts close together, with just enough room to slide in the twigs. Pile the twigs in, and the posts will hold them in place as they build up to form the jump. Make it as high as you please. Make a jump from craft sticks. Simply build up a jump by laying craft sticks one on top of the other to the desired height. You could use rubber bands or twist ties to keep the jump in place if you're worried about knocking it over Make a jump from scrap wood or wood blocks. Find wood pieces that already look as if they'll make a great jump. You can use them as they are if sufficiently large, or build them into a small wall jump. Turn the impermanent jumps into durable jumps by building them on a base then gluing or tying them into place. Keep them in a shoebox or similar container for safe keeping. Basic stone jumps Find suitable stones in the garden. You can use stones, pebbles, river rocks, clods of earth and so forth. Assemble the rocks into a wall by piling them one on top of the other. If you are concerned that the wall may fall over, prop them up with some twigs or craft sticks on the sides. Turn the impermanent jumps into durable jumps by building them on a base then gluing or tying them into place. Keep them in a shoebox or similar container for safe keeping. Basic bar jumps Find suitable materials to make bars with. Here are some suggestions for adding bars: Pipes are ideal bars and they don't cost very much. These can be arranged vertically and diagonally on a structure made from sticks, craft sticks or blocks of wood. If you want to make them very fancy, the ends can be colored with a marker. Use pipe cleaners. Pipe cleaners are nice and light to use for bars. They can balance very easily off different materials and have the added advantage of being bendable and can be twisted, as needed. Use ribbons. Ribbons from the scrap basket can be cut to any lengths as wished, and tied or held on as bars on a jump.
